description: From Middle English nere, ner, from Old English nēar (“nearer”, comparative of nēah (“nigh”)), influenced by Old Norse nær (“near”), both originating from Proto-Germanic *nēhwiz (“nearer”), comparative of the adverb *nēhw (“near”), from the adjective *nēhwaz, ultimately from Pre-Proto-Germanic *h₂nḗḱwos, a lengthened-grade adjective derived from Proto-Indo-European *h₂neḱ- (“to reach”).
Cognate with Old Frisian niār (“nearer”), Dutch naar (“to, towards”), German näher (“nearer”), Danish nær (“near, close”), Norwegian nær (“near, close”) Swedish nära (“near, close”). See also nigh.

Near appears to be derived from (or at the very least influenced by) the North Germanic languages; compare Danish nær (“near, close”), Norwegian nær (“near, close”) Swedish nära (“near, close”), as opposed to nigh, which continues the inherited West Germanic adjective, like Dutch na (“close, near”), German nah (“close, near, nearby”), Luxembourgish no (“nearby, near, close”). Both, however, are ultimately derived from the same Proto-Germanic root: *nēhw (“near, close”).

examples: I can't see near objects very clearly without my glasses.
Stay near at all times.
Synonym: close
Antonym: remote
The end is near.
The deceased man had no near relatives.

entries.meaning: Close to one's interests, affection, etc.; intimate; dear.
examples: A matter of near consequence to me.
a near friend

entries.meaning: Close to anything followed or imitated; not free, loose, or rambling.
examples: a version near to the original

entries.meaning: So as barely to avoid or pass injury or loss; close; narrow.
examples: a near escape
The two words are near synonyms.

entries.meaning: (Britain, in relation to a vehicle) On the side nearest to the kerb (the left-hand side if one drives on the left).
examples: The near front wheel came loose.
Antonym: off

entries.meaning: (dated) Next to the driver, when he is on foot; (US) on the left of an animal or a team.
examples: the near ox; the near leg
Don't be near with your pocketbook.

entries.meaning: (programming, not comparable) Within the currently selected segment in a segmented memory architecture.
examples: Antonym: far
a near pointer

entries.meaning: At or towards a position close in space or time.

examples: He was near unconscious when I found him.
I jumped into the near-freezing water.
I near ruptured myself trying to move the piano.

entries.meaning: The left side of a horse or of a team of horses pulling a carriage etc.
examples: Synonym: near side
Antonym: off side

entries.meaning: Physically close to, in close proximity to.
examples: There are habitable planets orbiting many of the stars near our Sun.
The voyage was near completion.

entries.meaning: Close to in nature or degree.
examples: His opinions are near the limit of what is acceptable.

verbs.description: near (third-person singular simple present nears, present participle nearing, simple past and past participle neared)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To come closer to; to approach.
examples: The ship nears the land.
